posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked:
Hello everyone, We currently have our robot in a trailer as our robotics closet (we do not have a shop) is being cleaned (It turns out that if you build a closet in a high school cafeteria and leave the door uninstalled, students will throw food in it). The temperature is going to get sub 32 degrees (20s) F. Is it bad to leave the trailer outside? It only contains the robot, our tools, and a few assorted electronics pieces (an extra IMU. An extra control system, motor contorllers etc). And two batteries.

Is this too cold for these things?

Lead acid batteries do not like to be stored in the cold, so you might bring those inside somewhere. The other stuff should be Ok (in the near term) as long as there is not a lot of moisture present. Just make sure it has plenty of time to come back up to room temperature before you turn anything on again.

posts.name: Brian Wagg
posts.cooked: Echoing above. From what I’ve heard/been told, make sure to move all your batteries inside. The rest will likely be fine for a short while.

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked: Thank you both. That makes sense. I will be sure to grab the batteries. It will have time to warm up as we have a few major repairs to make before we drive it in preparation for The Battle of The Bay this weekend.

posts.name: Patrick Freivald
posts.cooked:
Fully-charged lead-acid batteries have a freezing point of around -70C, which is one of the reasons they’re very popular in things like school buses and snow plows. As the battery drains, however, the acid converts to water, which of course freezes at 0C. A partially-charged battery will have a freezing point between those two numbers, depending on how charged/discharged it is.

This is why, for example, trickle chargers on marine batteries on boats stored outside (or in unheated buildings) in the winter do just fine in protecting those batteries from the cold–any heat generated is nominal, it’s the chemistry that matters.

So if they’re well-charged they should be just fine at or around 32F, though you’ll definitely notice performance degradation when they’re that cold if you try to use them on a robot.

posts.name: Smtopps
posts.cooked: not necessarily a problem but just watch out for moisture collected on the electronics. I would recommend not throwing a battery in it as soon as you bring it inside.

besides batteries, another factor to be aware of, depending how cold it gets, is that zip ties have a minimum temperature. below that, the latches can snap under load or when installing…ask how I know

posts.custom_user_title: just 3d print it, she'll be right

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: Petition to start referring to condensation as “unwanted water game”?

posts.name: Mr V
posts.cooked: As Pfreivald stated there is nothing wrong with storing lead acid batteries in sub freezing temps, as long as they have a reasonable state of charge. Millions of vehicles around the world have batteries that sit out in extreme cold and still start the vehicle.

Mr_V:

…as long as they have a reasonable state of charge.

…and as long as you are confident they have a reasonable state of charge, and as long as they don’t discharge over time… In any case, the safer answer is to bring them to a warmer location.

Not mentioned is the fact that the OP’s team was at a competition last weekend, so I was answering on the assumption that the batteries are likely drained.
Just waiting for someone more clever than me to make a “If you’re cold, they’re cold…put them in [insert joke here]” meme

posts.name: tkchan
posts.cooked: beside the batteries, I would also recommended bringing any/all electronics inside too (and of course any PC/laptops/etc).

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: think outside of the box from time to time

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked:
Thank you all. Our battery cart is in the school. There were two fully-charged batteries in the trailer and I did leave them in there. The laptops came inside. We shall see how everything is tomorrow afternoon. Saturday, we have another off-season comp. I marked @veg 's post as the solution though there is more info about batteries further down. I wish I could mark multiple threads as solutions. Thanks everyone for your help.

veg:

Not mentioned is the fact that the OP’s team was at a competition last weekend, so I was answering on the assumption that the batteries are likely drained.

Excellent catch. Thank you I should have mentioned it. Our battery cart only has one triple charger so as we rotate batteries, there tends to be a few fully charged (It is one of the places where we are inherently organized) at the end of the event.

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked: Be careful (wear gloves) carrying anything metal (like the robot!) inside when it’s cold, too.  Granted, it’s nothing like the sub-zero we can have here in MN during week-0, but I have seen people get frostbite carrying a robot inside from a trailer before!

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked: Thank you for the reminder. That is important.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
Just don’t let the students “ triple-dog dare ” each other

Mr.R_2:

Our battery cart only has one triple charger

I have been using one of these float chargers to keep up to 10 batteries in good condition for an overseas team over the last two years. I used a bunch of alligator clip test leads like these to interconnect them all in parallel. If you do use leads like these, pull the boot over the alligator clips back off the clips and check to see if the wires are soldered to the clip or if the stripped part is folded back over the insulation and crimped. Do this no matter where you purchase them. The ones I purchased online for myself and some at work went intermittent as the insulation slowly compressed over time.

link_counts.title: A Christmas Story | "Sticky Tongue" Clip | Warner Bros. Entertainment - YouTube

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked:
I too was thinking of that scene when @Jon_Stratis Mentioned the metal.

The single battery floating charger looks great. If we go that route for the other chargers, we will probably cut off the ends of the leads and crimp on an an SB connector.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
If you are going to use SB connectors, you can wire up a bunch of them in parallel on the output of the float charger so you can plug in all your batteries to the same float charger.

The team I was storing the batteries for had removed their 2 AWG battery cables and took them home so the alligator clips were the way to go.

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked: That is cool. I did not catch that you used one charger (though you said it). I guess it would be obvious that you need to wire them in parallel. Otherwise, you are talking major voltage. Do you wire up an indicator per battery so you know the status of each?

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
Since they are wired in parallel, they all end up at the same voltage.

I charged each one, individually, using a 4 A charger before connecting them in parallel. That gets them all to very nearly the same voltage. The voltages will “even out” a short time after being connected in parallel.

The other stuff should be Ok (in the near term) as long as there is not a lot of moisture present. Just make sure it has plenty of time to come back up to room temperature before you turn anything on…
